Take a picture. The type of picture taken is related to the picture setting. You can set the picture format by sending the command \href{#1-19-0}{\tt Set\+Picture\+Format}. You can also get the current picture format with \href{#1-20-0}{\tt Picture\+Format}. Please note that the time required to take the picture is highly related to this format. 

You can check if the picture taking is available with \href{#1-8-2}{\tt Picture\+State}. Also, please note that if your picture format is different from snapshot, picture taking will stop video recording (it will restart after that the picture has been taken). \begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

{\em \+\_\+pitch} & Pitch angle as signed percentage. copters\+: as signed percentage of the max pitch/roll setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]}~\newline
-\/100 corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards sky (drone will fly backward) corresponds to a pitch angle of max pitch/roll towards ground (drone will fly forward) value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter.~\newline
 fixed wings\+: as signed percentage of the physical max pitch of the wing, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} value makes the plane fly in direction of the sky value makes the plane fly in direction of the ground \\
\hline
{\em \+\_\+yaw} & Yaw rotation speed as signed percentage. copters\+: as signed percentage of the max yaw rotation speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]}.~\newline
-\/100 corresponds to a counter-\/clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed corresponds to a clockwise rotation of max yaw rotation speed value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter.~\newline
 fixed wings\+: more than a fixed value (75\% for the moment) triggers a circle. value will trigger a clockwise circling value will trigger a counter-\/clockwise circling \\
\hline
{\em \+\_\+gaz} & Throttle as signed percentage. copters\+: as signed percentage of the max vertical speed setting, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]}~\newline
-\/100 corresponds to a max vertical speed towards ground corresponds to a max vertical speed towards sky value may be clamped if necessary, in order to respect the maximum supported physical tilt of the copter. the landing phase, putting some positive gaz will cancel the land.~\newline
 fixed wings\+: as signed percentage of the physical max throttle, in range \mbox{[}-\/100, 100\mbox{]} value makes the plane fly slower value makes the plane fly faster \\

A filter modifies the response curve of an axis. As the preset filters list is empty, all filters are to be sent using the builder syntax. 

The builder syntax supports two types of filters\+: Multilinear and Exponential.

Multilinear filters create response curves made of multiple linear segments\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The default filter (A\+R\+MF;) is purely linear and create a single segment from the two implicit {\ttfamily \mbox{[}-\/1; -\/1\mbox{]}} and {\ttfamily \mbox{[}1; 1\mbox{]}} points.
\item Additionnal points can be added to the filter with the following syntax\+: {\ttfamily A\+R\+MF;x1$>$y1;...;xN$>$yN;}, where all numbers are floating point numbers in range {\ttfamily \mbox{[}-\/1; 1\mbox{]}}.
\item Additionnal points {\bfseries must} respect the following constraints \+: {\ttfamily x(\+N)$>$x(N-\/1)} and {\ttfamily y(\+N)$>$=y(N-\/1)}.
\end{DoxyItemize}

Exponential filters\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The syntax is {\ttfamily A\+R\+XF;C\+Px;C\+Py;}, where C\+Px and C\+Py are floating point numbers in range {\ttfamily \mbox{[}0; 1\mbox{]}}.
\item Best results are achieved when {\ttfamily C\+Px + C\+Py == 1} and {\ttfamily C\+Px $>$ C\+Py}.
\item If the control point is on the diagonal (i.\+e. {\ttfamily C\+Px == C\+Py}), then the resulting filter will be linear. \begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}
A command is not N\+U\+LL terminated and can contain N\+U\+LL bytes. 
\end{DoxyWarning}

Each action that can be mapped on an axis is identified by its mapping\+\_\+uid, which will be used in the \href{#4-14-2}{\tt set\+Axis\+Mapping} and \href{#4-15-0}{\tt current\+Axis\+Mappings} commands. The name is a human readable string, in english, describing the action. A special action named N\+O\+\_\+\+A\+C\+T\+I\+ON serves as the unmap action. This action can be bound to multiple axes to disable them. An \href{#4-15-3}{\tt all\+Available\+Axiss\+Mappings\+Sent} event is sent at the end of the list.

Any previous mapping for the given button will be removed, as a button can only be mapped to one action. To unmap a button, a N\+O\+\_\+\+A\+C\+T\+I\+ON mapping can be used (see the \href{#4-13-2}{\tt available\+Button\+Mappings} event). Some actions can not be mapped to two different buttons at the same time. In this case, the first button will automatically be set to N\+O\+\_\+\+A\+C\+T\+I\+ON, and the corresponding \href{#4-13-0}{\tt current\+Button\+Mappings} event will be fired.

Each action that can be mapped on a button is identified by its mapping\+\_\+uid, which will be used in the \href{#4-12-2}{\tt set\+Button\+Mapping} and \href{#4-13-0}{\tt current\+Button\+Mappings} commands. The name is a human readable string, in english, describing the action. A special action named N\+O\+\_\+\+A\+C\+T\+I\+ON serves as the unmap action. This action can be bound to multiple buttons to disable them. An \href{#4-13-3}{\tt all\+Available\+Buttons\+Mappings\+Sent} event is sent at the end of the list.

Change who is piloting the drone. By default, the Sky\+Controller is the source of piloting commands, and any connected application (i.\+e. Free\+Flight) can not send \href{#1-0-2}{\tt piloting commands} commands directly to the drone. When the piloting source is set to Controller, the Sky\+Controller will forward the controller commands to the drone, and won\textquotesingle{}t send any commands itself. The piloting source is automatically reset to Sky\+Controller when the controller is disconnected.
